articles.title: Computer Attack Slows Service at New York Times' Web Site
articles.authors: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition
articles.short_summary: A computer attack overwhelmed the New York Times' website during a high-traffic election night, highlighting vulnerabilities in internet security.
articles.summary: On election night in 1996, the New York Times' website faced a significant slowdown due to a computer attack that flooded its servers with requests. This incident was reminiscent of a previous attack on Public Access Networks Corp. (Panix), which had paralyzed their services. The attack method involved sending numerous fake requests to the server, consuming its resources and preventing legitimate users from accessing the site. Internet security expert William Cheswick remarked that such attacks reveal a critical vulnerability in the internet's infrastructure, suggesting an ongoing 'arms race' between security measures and hackers. The incident underscored the need for improved security protocols to handle such malicious activities effectively.
articles.historical_context: This article reflects the early days of widespread internet use and the growing awareness of cybersecurity issues, particularly during high-profile events like elections.
articles.target_audience: Security professionals, hackers, and individuals interested in the evolution of internet security.

articles.reference: Volume Seven, Issue Fifty, Phile #2 of 16
articles.title: [Chinese Hacker Convicted]
articles.short_summary: A Chinese hacker was fined for accessing the internet using others' accounts, marking a significant legal precedent in Hong Kong.
articles.summary: David Yip Shu-chew, a 27-year-old hacker from Hong Kong, was fined HK$125,000 for illegally accessing the internet through other people's accounts. This case marked a significant moment in Hong Kong's legal landscape, as Yip became the first individual charged under the Crimes Ordinance for accessing a computer with criminal intent. The judge imposed a fine and ordered Yip to compensate the affected internet service provider, while also warning him of potential jail time for any future misuse of the internet. This case highlights the legal ramifications of hacking and the increasing enforcement of cyber laws in the region.
articles.historical_context: This conviction occurred during a time when internet usage was rapidly expanding in Asia, and legal frameworks were struggling to keep pace with technological advancements.
articles.target_audience: Legal professionals, cybersecurity experts, and individuals interested in the intersection of law and technology.

articles.title: Phone 'Super Scanner' Alert
articles.short_summary: A new device that can clone mobile phones poses a significant threat to the UK cellphone industry, costing millions annually.
articles.summary: The introduction of a powerful new device known as the 'super-scanner' has raised alarms within the British cellphone industry, which already suffers losses of Â£200 million a year due to cellphone fraud. This device can capture the identification numbers of vulnerable analogue phones from a distance of half a mile, allowing criminals to clone phones without the need for victims to be on calls. The Federation of Communication Services has launched a campaign to outlaw the sale and use of such cloning equipment, emphasizing the urgent need for enhanced security measures in the mobile communications sector. While digital phones are currently safe from this technique, reports suggest that criminals are close to developing methods to clone digital devices as well.
articles.historical_context: This article highlights the vulnerabilities of early mobile phone technology and the ongoing battle against fraud in telecommunications.
articles.target_audience: Telecommunications professionals, security experts, and individuals interested in mobile technology.
